awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research conference “Algebra 2022 and Beyond." The aim of this event is to bring together established and early-career researchers in algebra to both disseminate recent work in the field and to foster collaborations and connections – especially among scholars from the Midwest. Under the broad umbrella of Algebra, the focus will be on three areas, algebraic number theory, arithmetic geometry, and group theory, which are among central areas of modern mathematics, with natural connections to physics, chemistry, and information science. The list of speakers will include established scholars whose participation in the event will contribute to the training of the next generation of algebraists. In particular, the conference will include a professional development workshop to help early-career mathematicians further their careers. 
 
The main research areas of the conference are algebraic number theory, arithmetic geometry, and group theory. The list of scholars who have agreed to lecture includes six invited speakers at International Congresses of Mathematicians. The conference will be forward-looking; speakers will be encouraged to aim their talks at broad audiences of algebraists and emphasize the connections among the three major mathematical areas of the conference. Funding provided by the grant will be used to support early career mathematicians and graduate students to attend the conference.  The conference proceedings will be published. For more information see the conference website https://math.indiana.edu/misc/mjlarsen2022/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From June 3, 2022 - June 5, 2022 we held

Algebra 2022 and Beyond, a conference in honor of the Mathematical contributions of Michael J. Larsen.

This conference was in the primary algebraic research areas of Michael J. Larsen: Algebraic Number Theory, Arithmetic Geometry and Group Theory. The talks were aimed at a broad swath of algebraists at all levels. It was our hope to foster interactions across these areas in the spirit of Michael?s own body of work.

There were 11 plenary speakers:

Renee Bell, UPenn
Ching-Li Chai, UPenn
Robert Guralnick, USC
Chun Yin Hui, U. of Hong Kong
Bo-Hae Im, KAIST
Chandrashekhar Khare, UCLA
Ayelet Lindenstrauss, Indiana
Aner Shalev, Hebrew University
Carlos Simpson, Universite Cote d'Azur
Donna Testermann, EPFL
Melanie, Harvard University

There were approximately 65 attendees, including 25 graduate students and 14 early career mathematicians (Postdocs or Assistant Professors). In addition to the 11 invited talks, there were 9 contributed talks by younger mathematicians:

Itay Glazer, Northwestern University
Be'eri Greenfield, University of California at San Diego
sung Min Lee, University of Illinois at Chicago
Eilidh McKemmie, Rutgers University
Hung Nguyen, University of Akron
Joshua Ruiter, Grinnell College
Chris Schroeder, Binghamton University
Shiang Tang, Purdue University
Erik Wallace, Hartwick College 

We also held a Professional Development Workshop during which mathematicians at various career stages described their career arcs and challenges faced for the benefit of graduate students, postdocs and assistant professors.  There was a lengthy question and answer session.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2023
Modified by: Pham H Tiep
